title: MOD sustainability and environmental appraisal tools handbook
withdrawn_explanation:
The suite of appraisal tool methodologies previously found in the SEAT Handbook can now be found in JSP 850 â€˜Infrastructure and Estate Policy, Standards and Guidanceâ€™. This should be accessed via Knowledge in Defence (KiD).

It includes:

  • Section 1: Summary Booklet
  • Section 2: Sustainability Appraisal (SA)
  • Section 3: Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA)
  • Section 4: Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA)
  • Section 5: Habitats Regulations Assessments (HRA)
  • Section 6: Defence Related Environmental Assessment Method (DREAM)
  • Section 7: Climate Impacts Risk Assessment Methodology (CIRAM)
  • Section 8: Linked Tools

title: Choosing and using oil separators, PPG3: prevent pollution
withdrawn_explanation:
All pollution prevention guidance (PPGs) that was previously maintained by the Environment Agency has been withdrawn from use and can now be found on The National Archives.

Pollution prevention guidance contained a mix of regulatory requirements and good practice advice. The Environment Agency does not provide â€˜good practiceâ€™ guidance.

Current guidance explains how to: report an environmental incident, get permission to discharge to surface or groundwater, manage business and commercial waste, store oil and any oil storage regulations, discharge sewage with no mains drainage, work on or near water and manage water on land.

title: Opra for EPR: Operational risk appraisal
withdrawn_explanation:
Attendance levels for technically competent managers

Until we publish new guidance on attendance levels, continue to use the 3 OPRA attributes of complexity, emissions and location to calculate the attendance levels for technically competent managers of operations authorised by bespoke permits.

For waste operations, see:

  • pages 5 to 13 - Opra for EPR: Annex B: Opra scheme for waste facilities
  • complexity, emissions, location tab - Opra for EPR: Waste facilities spreadsheet
  • pages 10 to 14 - Opra for EPR: How to complete an Opra for waste facilities spreadsheet

For waste installations, see:

  • pages 5 to 12, 21 to 24 and 28 to 37 - Opra for EPR: Annex A - Opra scheme for installations
  • Opra for EPR: Installations spreadsheet
  • Opra for EPR: How to complete an Opra for installations spreadsheet

title: Water discharge and groundwater activity permits: additional guidance
withdrawn_explanation:
This publication has been replaced by guidance on:

  • Site-specific quality numeric permit limits: discharges to surface water and groundwater
  • Domestic sewage: discharges to surface water and groundwater
  • Calculating dry weather flow
  • Reservoir discharges: consents, permits and risk assessment
  • Waste water treatment works: treatment, monitoring and compliance limits
  • Water companies: operator self monitoring (OSM) environmental permits
  • Water companies: environmental permits for storm overflows and emergency overflows
  • Water companies: control of chemicals used for dosing at waste water treatment works
  • Water companies: water treatment works discharge limits for environmental permits

You can also find this content on the collection page for Water discharge and groundwater activity environmental permits.

The Environment Agency is currently updating guidance on:

  • Water companies: discharge disinfection (UV and membrane), efficacy monitoring and reporting requirements and assessing compliance
  • Water companies: discharge flow measurement and reporting requirements and assessing compliance

title: Works in, near or over watercourses, PPG5: prevent pollution
withdrawn_explanation:
All pollution prevention guidance (PPGs) that was previously maintained by the Environment Agency has been withdrawn from use and can now be found on The National Archives.

Pollution prevention guidance contained a mix of regulatory requirements and good practice advice. The Environment Agency does not provide â€˜good practiceâ€™ guidance.

Current guidance explains how to: report an environmental incident, get permission to discharge to surface or groundwater, manage business and commercial waste, store oil and any oil storage regulations, discharge sewage with no mains drainage, work on or near water and manage water on land.

title: Code for sustainable homes: case studies volume 2
withdrawn_explanation:
Following the technical housing standards review, the government has withdrawn the code for sustainable homes, aside from the management of legacy cases.

Legacy cases are those where residential developments are legally contracted to apply a code policy (eg. affordable housing funded through the national Affordable Housing Programme 2015 to 2018, or earlier programme), or where planning permission has been granted subject to a condition stipulating discharge of a code level, and developers are not appealing the condition or seeking to have it removed or varied. In these instances it is possible to continue to conduct code assessments.

Details of the new approach to the setting of technical housing standards in England were announced on 27 March 2015 and a new set of streamlined national technical standards were published. A planning written ministerial statement was also published which outlined the governmentâ€™s policy on the application of these technical standards for plan making and decision-taking.

The code for sustainable homes webpage is available for the purposes of administering legacy cases only.

title: Code for sustainable homes: case studies volume 3
withdrawn_explanation:
Following the technical housing standards review, the government has withdrawn the code for sustainable homes, aside from the management of legacy cases.

Legacy cases are those where residential developments are legally contracted to apply a code policy (eg. affordable housing funded through the national Affordable Housing Programme 2015 to 2018, or earlier programme), or where planning permission has been granted subject to a condition stipulating discharge of a code level, and developers are not appealing the condition or seeking to have it removed or varied. In these instances it is possible to continue to conduct code assessments.

Details of the new approach to the setting of technical housing standards in England were announced on 27 March 2015 and a new set of streamlined national technical standards were published. A planning written ministerial statement was also published which outlined the governmentâ€™s policy on the application of these technical standards for plan making and decision-taking.

The code for sustainable homes webpage is available for the purposes of administering legacy cases only.

title: Sewage treatment and disposal where there is no foul sewer, PPG4
withdrawn_explanation:
All pollution prevention guidance (PPGs) that was previously maintained by the Environment Agency has been withdrawn from use and can now be found on The National Archives.

Pollution prevention guidance contained a mix of regulatory requirements and good practice advice. The Environment Agency does not provide â€˜good practiceâ€™ guidance.

Current guidance explains how to: report an environmental incident, get permission to discharge to surface or groundwater, manage business and commercial waste, store oil and any oil storage regulations, discharge sewage with no mains drainage, work on or near water and manage water on land.
